stream_context.summary: Kaze reports major stability/refactor work (game running on N64 again, crashes fixed) and then focuses the stream on implementing a new small enemy for the current ice/castle level: ice “ravens” that spawn from the ground, walk along surfaces, turn at edges/corners, and disappear. The session includes performance/engine optimizations, a Fast64 export gotcha, collaboration with Zeina (model) and Biobak (design pivot), and a broader design discussion about movement tech (dive-jump) and avoiding puzzle-heavy level design.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains meaningful project-status updates (refactor/stability, N64 performance), a concrete new enemy implementation with a design pivot driven by Biobak, and a significant design-philosophy discussion about whether to nerf/remove a player movement mechanic after feedback from Dan Salvato.

findings.summary: Kaze refactored parts of the RTUI codebase during the week, got the game running on N64 again, and fixed many crashes, making the build significantly more stable.
He replaced the first overworld with a new debug overworld to support development/testing after refactors.

He implemented a new rendering/engine approach that allows rendering certain HUD/overlay (“hot”) elements on-demand via his delegate system instead of hard-coding, saving a small amount of time globally (he estimates a couple microseconds).
He proposes a future optimization: placing framebuffers into separate memory segments, expecting a ~2–3% performance gain (which he frames as roughly a full FPS on N64).

The ice/castle course is intended to be a surreal ice-palace/ice-dungeon with “mindfuck” elements; Kaze pushes back on puzzle elements, arguing the hack should remain a “pure platformer” because puzzles conflict with the game’s core design.
findings.quote: I don't think puzzle elements really fit because this is like a pure platformer; puzzle stuff kind of seems against the basic design of this game.

findings.summary: The team adds a small “raven” enemy (from Yoshi’s Island inspiration) and decides it should function as an ice minion: pop out of the ground/walls, walk a short path (including along walls), turn at edges/corners, then disappear—chosen because it’s both cooler and easier to program than free-roaming AI.

Biobak influences a mid-stream design pivot: instead of figuring out complex wall-following turning logic for free-moving ravens, Kaze adopts Biobak’s suggestion to make them spawn/disappear as ice minions, reducing programming complexity while improving presentation.
findings.quote: Dang, you have some convincing arguments, Biobak… It's cooler and easier to program.

findings.summary: Kaze struggles with and then resolves enemy orientation/turning issues involving angles vs. surface normals; he notes that “working with angles and normals at the same time sucks,” and implements an angles-to-normal/vector approach for correct spawning/orientation on geometry.

He identifies a Fast64 export/serialization issue related to order of operations/left shifts and fixes it by adding brackets; he jokingly blames Lilaa/Fast64 after incorrect values were coming through into the game.
findings.quote: This is a Fast64 bug… you need to add brackets to that.

findings.summary: Kaze revisits the “dive jump” movement tech after Dan Salvato comments it’s against Mario 64’s design because it allows midair angle correction; Kaze considers limiting it so it becomes an advanced minor advantage rather than a powerful midair correction tool, to preserve Mario 64’s commitment-based jumps and keep weaker players from relying on it.

Project scope/progress snapshot: Kaze says the game targets ~180 stars; he mentions having ~12 levels done plus side levels, and that he’s currently working on the 13th level, with boss levels, two side levels, and a “huge part of the overworld” still remaining, followed by bug/beta testing.

The raven boss (“Raffle the Raven”) is planned for this course with moon/cosmic elements; Kaze implies it will not follow standard SM64 boss conventions (special attacks/knockback mechanics) and may be colored black to work with a moon-themed cutscene; he clarifies the boss will be an actual raven while the small enemies are ice minions.

biobak.summary: Proposes turning the small ravens into ice minions that spawn from the ground, walk briefly (including around a corner), then disappear—framing it as both visually cooler and far easier to program than persistent pathfinding/wall-following AI.

Suggests a more involved interaction idea (punch to make them slide and shatter on impact), which Kaze notes is feasible but would require additional plane movement/raycasting work; it is not adopted in this stream.

zeina.summary: Provides the raven model asset used for the enemy; Kaze imports it and adjusts sizing/material approach based on level needs (eventually deciding small enemies are ice-minions while the boss remains a true raven).

findings.summary: Gives outside-design feedback that the hack’s dive-jump mechanic conflicts with Mario 64’s commitment-based jump design by enabling midair angle correction; this triggers Kaze’s reconsideration of the move’s power/role.
Kaze mentions reviewing Michi’s functions and integrating some of them into the codebase during refactoring work.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze describes the overall difficulty and endurance required to build a full-scale N64 ROM hack with many levels, systems, and polish.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The N64 is so much stronger than people give it credit for.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while discussing native hardware performance/optimizations and the project running near 60 FPS on real N64.

key_stories.title: Refactor week leads to N64 stability and a debug overworld
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains he spent the week refactoring RTUI’s codebase and regained N64 compatibility while fixing numerous crashes. He also replaces the first overworld with a debug overworld, emphasizing iteration speed and stability during heavy engine/level work.
key_stories.challenge: Refactors caused instability and crashes, risking loss of progress and making testing unreliable on target hardware.
key_stories.process: Refactor and re-integrate systems carefully, fix crashes, validate on N64 again, and swap in a debug overworld for easier testing.
key_stories.outcome: A more stable build and a development-oriented overworld setup, enabling faster iteration on levels/enemies.

key_stories.title: Ice raven enemy pivots from complex AI to spawn-and-disappear minions
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts by attempting a more complex wall-following raven behavior with turning logic tied to geometry raycasts and rotations. After Biobak suggests making them ice minions that pop out, walk a short segment, then disappear, Kaze adopts the approach for both coolness and implementation simplicity.
key_stories.challenge: Free-roaming wall-walking ravens required complicated turning/orientation logic and raised questions about placement and purpose.
key_stories.process: Prototype movement/turning, confront complexity (angles/normals, animation timing), then redesign as spawner-based minions and implement the spawner behavior and timing.
key_stories.outcome: Working enemy concept that fits the ice theme and is easier to place and tune; remaining work depends on finishing the level layout/visuals.
key_stories.key_quote: It's cooler and easier to program.

open_questions.topic: Dive-jump mechanic redesign after Dan Salvato feedback
open_questions.context: Kaze believes the current dive-jump allows too much midair angle correction, conflicting with Mario 64’s committed jump arcs and potentially trivializing mistakes for skilled players while remaining inaccessible to novices.
questions: What specific player-testing or level-design problems made the dive-jump feel ‘too powerful’—were there particular jumps/sections it broke?
What final direction did you choose: nerf (reduced angle change), higher execution barrier, limited contexts, or removal?
How do you decide which movement tech is ‘advanced reward’ versus ‘core expected tool’ for a 180-star hack?
Did you adjust any existing courses that were implicitly designed around the old dive-jump behavior?

open_questions.topic: Raven boss fight design (moon/cosmic cutscene and mechanics)
open_questions.context: Kaze hints that “Raffle the Raven” will be a boss with moon/cosmic elements and special knockback/attack patterns (not classic SM64 boss rules). He also mentions a possible black coloration to support a moon-themed cutscene.
questions: What is the narrative/visual concept of the moon/cosmic sequence, and how does it connect to the ice-palace theme?
What are the concrete player verbs in the boss fight—how do you ‘knock him back’ and what triggers phases?
Why make the boss black for the cutscene—was it a technical readability constraint, lighting/material limitation, or a story/character choice?
How do you balance ‘Yoshi’s Island respect’ with ‘Mario 64 readability’ for a boss silhouette and attacks?

open_questions.topic: Performance strategy and N64 target validation
open_questions.context: Kaze claims near-60 FPS on real N64, mentions micro-optimizations (hot-element rendering) and a planned framebuffer segmentation change for a 2–3% boost; he also notes he can’t currently boot his N64 due to being in Canada with a European plug.
questions: What’s your actual performance target across the whole game (true 60, ‘near 60’, or per-level budgets), and how do you measure it?
How often do you test on real N64 vs emulator, and what’s your workflow when you can’t access hardware?
Did the new hot-element/delegate rendering system remove any major bottleneck elsewhere, or is it part of an ‘every microsecond counts’ philosophy?
Did the framebuffer segmentation idea end up working, and what tradeoffs (memory fragmentation, complexity, compatibility) did it introduce?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 pipeline reliability and exporter pitfalls
open_questions.context: A behavior value mismatch was traced to an order-of-operations/left-shift issue in exported values, fixed by adding brackets; Kaze labels it a Fast64 bug and notes values came through wrong until corrected.
questions: How often do toolchain/exporter issues (Fast64) create silent gameplay bugs, and how do you detect them?
Do you maintain any conventions or code-side validation to catch ‘exported numeric values are wrong’ errors early?
Was this an actual Fast64 bug, or a usage/format expectation (e.g., needing explicit parentheses)?
How has dependence on Fast64 shaped your iteration speed compared to pre-decomp ASM-era workflows?

open_questions.topic: Ice raven minion final behavior and placement role
open_questions.context: Kaze ends with a working enemy but admits placement depends on finishing the level; he also debates whether they should freeze or just damage, and whether bounce-top interaction should remain.
questions: What final role do the ice ravens play in the level’s rhythm—pressure in traversal, timing hazards, or atmosphere?
Did you choose ‘freeze’ status, plain damage, or a hybrid (e.g., freeze on wall-walk only)? Why?
How did you decide whether the player can jump on them versus needing punches/sliding mechanics?
What specific parts of the ice-castle layout were designed around raven spawners once the level visuals/paths were finalized?
